content.description:
Follow broken blocks to the left of "

Too Much Nooky...

" and up to the overhang above.  Climb through the first weakness left of the bolt line on small crimps to the anchors of "

Too Much...

."
content.location: This is left of the leftmost bolt line.

climbs.name: Too Much Nooky, Not Enough Sleep

content.description:
This fine little climb is just to the right of

Whole Lotta Sober

.  Climb up through two small roofs with the crux at the second roof. The rock is well featured and the climbing is mostly easier than 5.9 with a short crux.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the furthest left line of bolts on the wall.  It starts to the right of some jumbled blocks at the base.  Descend from a two bolt anchor at the top.

content.description:
This is named for the precipitous thunder boomers that typically roll in on summer afternoons in July and August.  The rain held off long enough for the ascent but not long enough to soak us on our short hike out.  Wet dogs smell like, well, wet dogs in the back of your buddies car :).  Follow the broken crack system just left of

Learning Curve

.  Place some questionable gear before pulling through the roof onto the delicate face.  Dainty moves and a step to the left deposit you at the anchors for

Practice Run

.
content.protection: Small nuts and a few cams.
content.location:
This is left of

Learning Curve

and right of

Practice Run

.

climbs.name: Practice Run
climbs.fa: Mike Lane's bolts, Tod Anderson's anchors?

content.description: Follow the 2nd bolt line from the right.  Short cruxes are encountered at the overhangs which are easier if tall (still fun for the small though).  Head up the face aiming for the center of a small arch.  The yellow lichen bulge is the first difficulty, then pull over the arch onto really cool chicken heads, and head up and slightly right to a shared anchor.  Clipping the anchor is probably the real crux, since everything is a little sloping and insecure (compared to all the in-cut holds to which you are now accustomed)....
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor (one Metolius rap hanger and one cold shut).
content.location: This is the 2nd bolt line from the right.

content.description: This route is very well bolted and is a good climb for a new leader or those who are height challenged. Thin, delicate climbing starts the route but the crux is pulling the roof.  Fun!
content.protection: Many bolts.  "Rampart Range Rocks" says it has 11 bolts, but we had 12 draws and ended up with a few left over.  Bring 10 draws and you should be OK.
content.location: This is the second bolted line from the left and has more bolts than any other route on the crag.

content.description: This starts just to the left of a big tree at the base.  The face is well-featured with holds and the bolts lead to a stance on a sloping ledge below a roof.  Turning the roof is the crux and involves a long reach.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the furthest right of the bolted lines at the crag. Descend from a two bolt, cold shut anchor.

content.description:
Climb up over broken rock to a small roof in left-facing corner, place some good gear, and turn the roof on good but small holds. Climb the slightly runout face above to the anchors of

Too Much...

.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 3 inches. Bring some sling to extend the pro under the roof.
content.location: The route climbs the broken rock and roofs on the left side of The Training Ground.

content.description:
This one starts on the slab just right of

Passing the Baton

.  The crux is the roof, but it is turned on monster handlebar holds.  You can kick your feet loose here for fun.  The rock above the roof is well featured with "alligator skin" holds, and the climbing here is super fun.
content.protection:
8 bolts.  Shares an anchor with

Passing the Baton

.
content.location:
This is the bolted route in the center of the wall.  It turns the roof just left of a right-facing arch.  Descend from the anchor on

Passing the Baton

.
